qas.question: What type of climate was normal in the Ordovician period?
What ice age signaled the end of the normal climate in the Ordovician period?
Oxygen from what kind of fossil were used to date the Hirnantian faunal stage?
How many years is the Hirnantian faunal stage believed to have lasted?
What started to develop on Gondwana as it moved over the south pole?
What faunel stage triggered the greenhouse conditions of the Ordovician?
What showed that the ice age lasted longer than originally thought?
What is know believed to have lasted more than 1.5 million years?
What levels rose in the atmosphere prior to the ice age?
Where where the oranisms laffected byrisingcarbon dioxide levels?

context: The most-commonly accepted theory is that these events were triggered by the onset of an ice age, in <a1_0>the <b5_0>Hirnantian faunal stage<b5_0/><a1_0/> that ended the long, <a0_0>stable greenhouse conditions<a0_0/> typical of the Ordovician. <b7_0>The ice age<b7_0/> was probably not as long-lasting as once thought; study of <b6_0>oxygen isotopes in fossil <a2_0>brachiopods<b6_0/><a2_0/> shows that it was probably no longer than <a3_0>0.5 to 1.5 million years<a3_0/>. The event was preceded by a fall in atmospheric <b8_0>carbon dioxide<b8_0/> (from 7000ppm to 4400ppm) which selectively affected the <b9_0>shallow seas<b9_0/> where most organisms lived. As the southern supercontinent Gondwana drifted over the South Pole, <a4_0>ice caps<a4_0/> formed on it. Evidence of these ice caps have been detected in Upper Ordovician rock strata of North Africa and then-adjacent northeastern South America, which were south-polar locations at the time.
